text: Hey fam! :sparkles: Anyone here use a 'hello bar' or something similar for your company blog? Does it work well to capture leads? Which tool do you use for it?

elements.text: Hey fam!

text:
Had been using hellobar for around a year with good results. Recently moved to Get Site Control as the design options are better (in our opinion).

We consistently get over 100 clicks per week.

text:
You can definitely embed the review using the widgets those sites offer no problem.

Where it gets a bit tricky is if they left an anonymous/semi-anonymous (e.g., Hiba A.) review and you want to identify them as Hiba Amin on your website in a quote or graphic. You might want to just give them a courtesy review.

text:
Hey folks! Bit of a long question, but I'm looking for some insight on how to structure a marketing team. The B2B company I work for has two mostly non-overlapping core business lines with different target audiences that fall under the same brand.

We're looking to scale up our marketing efforts and the question has been raised as to whether we should should consider splitting our marketing team by our two service lines. Right now we're just focusing on getting the basics in place like website content, a regular blog, social media, email campaigns, etc.

We're aiming to grow from a team of 2 FTE to 5-6 FTE, plus freelance resources (writers, designers, etc.)

How I see it:

• Pros of one team: bigger-picture view of the whole company, more resource flexibility/ability to dial one business line up and down, more cross training,
• Pros of two teams: team develops more subject matter/customer expertise, each business line gets appropriate focus, 
My thought is that the one team approach is more "agile" (buzzword alert) for a small team, but at present it always seems to pull our focus towards only one service. That may also just be because our current team capacity is so stretched.

Has anyone else faced a similar scenario? I'd love your advice!

elements.text:
Hey folks! Bit of a long question, but I'm looking for some insight on how to structure a marketing team. The B2B company I work for has two mostly non-overlapping core business lines with different target audiences that fall under the same brand.

We're looking to scale up our marketing efforts and the question has been raised as to whether we should should consider splitting our marketing team by our two service lines. Right now we're just focusing on getting the basics in place like website content, a regular blog, social media, email campaigns, etc.

We're aiming to grow from a team of 2 FTE to 5-6 FTE, plus freelance resources (writers, designers, etc.)

How I see it:
Pros of one team: bigger-picture view of the whole company, more resource flexibility/ability to dial one business line up and down, more cross training,
Pros of two teams: team develops more subject matter/customer expertise, each business line gets appropriate focus,

My thought is that the one team approach is more "agile" (buzzword alert) for a small team, but at present it always seems to pull our focus towards only one service. That may also just be because our current team capacity is so stretched.

Has anyone else faced a similar scenario? I'd love your advice!

text: Yes. It’s unlikely you’ll be able to get equal resources on both teams so you’re going to have to figure out how to split some of it anyway.

elements.text: Yes. It’s unlikely you’ll be able to get equal resources on both teams so you’re going to have to figure out how to split some of it anyway.

text: Thanks Cassandra! Agreed.

elements.text: Thanks Cassandra! Agreed.

text:
Splitting 5-6 people sounds _*really*_ hard. Different in a 15-person team where you could have 2 fo each type of hire (ops, writers, campaign managers, etc.) I’d say hire one person to do each role well and work on both.

What will be tricky is prioritizing the lines and projects for each as a manager/leader vs. having the team understand how to work with both, I think. (Good marketers will know how  to do it, ask the right questions, and figure it out.)  Sounds more like you’ll need alignment on how you chose priorities…data and targets for each will hopefully be your best friend here.

One thought: I suppose if the personas and product lines are SUPER different, maybe *just* the content roles need to be split/focused for that level of expertise. But you could probably find freelance experts instead, and just have one awesome internal content manager to act as flight controller there…

Best of luck! Seems like you’re you’re being thoughtful in your approach and it will all work out :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Another idea: Keep the team as a whole and reimagine the in-house marketing team as a separate agency. The two "products" are your clients. Then, designate or hire two people to be "client reps/product managers." They work with the "client/product team" and are the knowledge bearers, project managers, cheerleaders, strategists, etc. for the different "client/products/audiences." If that makes any sense ...

elements.text: Another idea: Keep the team as a whole and reimagine the in-house marketing team as a separate agency. The two "products" are your clients. They work with the "client/product team" and are the knowledge bearers, project managers, cheerleaders, strategists, etc. for the different "client/products/audiences." If that makes any sense ...

And <@U01BLESEU1E> I love that approach. Or even having one internal PM/account manager role whose focus is to manage our stakeholders.

text:
Assuming you need relevant images to break text, I'd advice you to bank on embeds wherever possible. For example if you want to quote a stat, websites like Statista  offer embed codes that you can add to your CMS. You can use the same tactic to add relevant example by embedding social posts to reinforce a thought such as tweets, Instagram or FB posts.


You don't need to give credit when you take a screen grab of say a website etc, but you definitely do when you want to use an image from the web. When doing so save the image and then add a credit link when uploading [example source: <http://animalz.com|animalz.com>]
Hope this helps!

elements.text:

You don't need to give credit when you take a screen grab of say a website etc, but you definitely do when you want to use an image from the web. When doing so save the image and then add a credit link when uploading [example source:
animalz.com

]
Hope this helps!

text:
May definitely need to embed some stats and social posts. Thanks! 

As for my second question, I should have been clearer. I was wondering people's approaches to deciding which images they'll use based on the source website. For example, if the image is good and relevant, do you care if it's from a small-time website?
